<?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" media="screen" href="/~d/styles/rss2full.xsl"?><?xml-stylesheet type="text/css" media="screen" href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/~d/styles/itemcontent.css"?><rss xmlns:media="http://search.yahoo.com/mrss/" xmlns:feedburner="http://rssnamespace.org/feedburner/ext/1.0" version="2.0"><channel><title>Top Stories</title><link>http://discovermagazine.com/rss/master-feeds/top-stories</link><description>The best content on DiscoverMagazine.com.</description><docs>http://backend.userland.com/rss</docs><lastBuildDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 21:01:39 GMT</lastBuildDate><atom10:link xmlns:atom10="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" rel="self" type="application/rss+xml" href="http://feeds.feedburner.com/DiscoverTopStories" /><feedburner:info uri="discovertopstories" /><atom10:link xmlns:atom10="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom" rel="hub" href="http://pubsubhubbub.appspot.com/" /><item><title>The Smell of the Cinema: Human Chemical Signals?</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/Tvsmr3flU74/</link><description>The air in a cinema contains a chemical cocktail emitted by the audience - and the emotional tone of the movie influences the molecular composition of the cloud.

That's according to a striking set of results from researchers Johnathan Williams and colleagues who took air samples from two 230-seater screens of a cinema in Germany over a period of two weeks.





Here's an example of the chemical trace associated with shows of the movie "The Hunger Games 2: Catching Fire", featuring three</description><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 21:01:39 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/?p=7741</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/files/2016/05/cinema.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/files/2016/05/cinema.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/?p=7741</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>As El Niño fades, here comes La Niña</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/fBuzGLSKErM/</link><description>A big blob of cold water is rising from the depths in the equatorial Pacific, heralding the likely arrival of La Niña by fall


What a difference a few months make. In January, El Niño was still going strong. But now, not only is it waning but there is a 75 percent chance that its opposite — La Niña — will develop by fall, according to the latest monthly update from the Climate Prediction Center.

SEE ALSO: If La Niña follows the current super El Niño, it will probably be bad news for droug</description><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 19:51:01 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/?p=13410</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/files/2016/05/SST.gif</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/files/2016/05/SST.gif</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/?p=13410</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Computer Algorithm Turns Videos into Living Van Goghs</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/SrbQeNL-_54/</link><description>

Computers are becoming rather versatile copycats, thanks to deep-learning algorithms.

Just last year, researchers “trained” machines to transfer the brushstrokes of iconic artists onto any still image. Now, Manuel Ruder and a team of computer scientists from the University of Freiburg in Germany have taken the technology a step further: They're altering videos. The team’s style transfer algorithm makes clips from Ice Age or the television show Miss Marple appear as living paintings crafte</description><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 19:25:27 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15310</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/ice-age.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/ice-age.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15310</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>If There's Life on Mars, How Should We Treat It?</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/YeyXlt6HTS4/</link><description>

NASA’s chief scientist recently announced that “…we’re going to have strong indications of life beyond Earth within a decade, and I think we’re going to have definitive evidence within 20 to 30 years.” Such a discovery would clearly rank as one of the most important in human history and immediately open up a series of complex social and moral questions. One of the most profound concerns is about the moral status of extraterrestrial life forms. Since humanities scholars are only just now begi</description><pubDate>Thu, 12 May 2016 16:19:13 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/?p=6697</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/files/2016/05/mt-sharp.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/files/2016/05/mt-sharp.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/?p=6697</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Watch: False Killer Whales Hunt Down a Shark</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/qHNG_CFX5Wg/</link><description>

A high-speed chase off the coast of Australia claimed the life of a juvenile shark after it was hunted and eaten by a group of false killer whales.

Video of the hunt was captured by photographer Bruno Kataoka and broadcast on local TV station 7 News Sydney. The hunt went down off the coast of Cronulla, a suburb of Sydney. Kataoka spotted the whales chasing their prey while flying a drone with an camera attached, and he followed the hunt until a whale lunged from below and captured the sha</description><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 19:06:11 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15281</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/Screen-Shot-2016-05-11-at-1.30.02-PM-1024x576.png</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/Screen-Shot-2016-05-11-at-1.30.02-PM-1024x576.png</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15281</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Extreme Fossil Hunters Dig the Dirt in Antarctica</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/nQzSQlMZ5Tk/</link><description>

A recent expedition to Antarctica has returned with a cache of fossils and data gathered over the course of almost two months of work on the frozen continent.

Before you ask what they found, however, let's get to the real question: What were they even doing there in the first place? Hunting for fossils in the most inaccessible and inhospitable continent on the planet, where over 99 percent of the ground is covered in solid ice,  seems like a tall order, verging on an exercise in masochism</description><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 15:12:35 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/?p=6666</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/Screen-Shot-2016-05-09-at-4.15.16-PM-1024x678.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/Screen-Shot-2016-05-09-at-4.15.16-PM-1024x678.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/?p=6666</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>The Myth of the Brain</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/-pOA4TQDTzg/</link><description>Can neuroscience really make us smarter, richer and sexier?



In recent years the brain has become a cultural icon. We've started looking to neuroscience to answer all kinds of personal and social questions - and solve all kinds of everyday problems. It seems like wherever you turn you’ll find someone claiming that neuroscience can help us to understand the world better and achieve more.

In my new YouTube video The Myth of the Brain, I explain why 99% of these claims are rubbish.

[emb</description><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 07:28:17 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/?p=7738</guid><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/?p=7738</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Spiraling global warming</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/g-EeDdHLQBI/</link><description>Clear, simple and compelling: a visualization of the rise in our planet's average temperature from 1850 to the present


I spotted this animated visualization over at the Washington Post's awesome Capital Weather Gang site today, and I found it so compelling that I had to share it here at ImaGeo. Click on the graphic above to watch the animation on Twitter.

Credit goes to Jason Samenow at WashPo for jumping on this. Check out his article here. Climate scientist Ed Hawkins posted the visual</description><pubDate>Wed, 11 May 2016 02:03:36 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/?p=13391</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/files/2016/05/Screenshot_5_10_16_6_56_PM.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/files/2016/05/Screenshot_5_10_16_6_56_PM.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/?p=13391</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>These Idioms Are Destroyed by Science</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/3S5ivUXaJfk/</link><description>

A recent study from two undergraduates at the University of Leicester has proven, once and for all, that Justin Timberlake doesn't know what he's talking about.

In a short paper, the students demonstrate that it is physically impossible for a person to cry a river. Even if we made every person on Earth watch Titanic while simultaneously listening to Sarah McLachlan, and then gathered the inevitable flood of tears, all of humanity still wouldn't fill a river.

As a benchmark, they used t</description><pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 20:44:01 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15244</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/Screen-Shot-2016-05-10-at-2.50.23-PM-1024x576.png</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/Screen-Shot-2016-05-10-at-2.50.23-PM-1024x576.png</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15244</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Lessons from 'Living Cadavers'</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/WX4mAp8FE9U/</link><description>

The dead, the headlines read, might soon be brought back to life.

As pop-science headlines tend to, they blew the actual research proposal out of proportion, but the premise is real: The ReAnima Project recently received “ethical permission” from the government of India to take 20 patients who’ve been declared clinically brain dead, and try to restore a limited range of brain functions using cutting-edge neuroscience techniques.

When we get past the knee-jerk references to zombies and </description><pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 20:01:36 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/?p=6669</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/files/2016/05/shutterstock_210811285.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/files/2016/05/shutterstock_210811285.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/crux/?p=6669</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Watch tiny, dark Mercury glide across the luminous face of the Sun in glorious timelapse detail</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/F9WfMHkVC2E/</link><description>

Yesterday's transit of Mercury between the Sun and Earth was captured by countless amateur and professional astrophotographers alike, including Discover's photo editor, Ernie Mastroianni. Make sure to check out his post about it, which includes a spectacular image of the transit, here.

Now, the folks at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center have used images acquired by the Solar Dynamics Observatory spacecraft to create a series of timelapse animations stitched together in one video showing </description><pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 19:10:27 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/?p=13381</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/files/2016/05/Screenshot_5_10_16_10_58_AM-2.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/files/2016/05/Screenshot_5_10_16_10_58_AM-2.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/?p=13381</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Kepler Planet Hunters Announce 1,200 New Exoplanets</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/8t9DAkONecc/</link><description>




Today, researchers on NASA’s Kepler planet hunting mission didn’t announce one new interesting planet, as they usually do. Instead, they announced about 1,200 of them.

That more than doubles the number of confirmed planets in the catalog. As of yesterday, the listed number stood at 1,041 confirmations. The new planets aren’t a result of the K2 mission, though. Instead, it’s about new software that enabled Kepler researchers to parse out the signal from noise in candidate planets.

</description><pubDate>Tue, 10 May 2016 17:16:14 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15245</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/452b_artistconcept_beautyshot.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/452b_artistconcept_beautyshot.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15245</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Image of the Day: The Transit of Mercury</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/DrQiOI8NdVE/</link><description>

As astronomical events go, Mercury’s solar transit was not as spectacular as say, a solar eclipse, but many observers on this sunny Boston day enjoyed the view of a relatively rare event last seen nearly 10 years ago. Some were getting their first-ever glimpse of the innermost planet. As seen through my telescope with a solar-safe filter, Mercury appeared to be little more than a diminutive dot as it drifted across the solar face, which is nearly 160 times its apparent diameter. The innermos</description><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 17:26:58 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15197</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/transit160509_815.jpg-1024x533.jpeg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/transit160509_815.jpg-1024x533.jpeg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15197</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Canada wildfire could be the kickoff to a record-setting summer for Earth's northern reaches</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/qAtojLnaVF0/</link><description>The same warmth that fueled the Fort McMurray wildfire has been setting up the Arctic for extraordinary losses of sea ice


The rampaging wildfire that blazed through the city of Fort McMurray in Alberta, destroying an estimated 1,600 homes, will likely continue burning for months to come.

SEE ALSO: Satellite images show Fort McMurray, Canada under assault from the rampaging wildfire nicknamed "the beast"

This should come as no surprise, given the astonishing warmth that has gripped mos</description><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 15:27:59 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/?p=13313</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/files/2016/05/ASINA_May_Fig3anim-2.gif</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/files/2016/05/ASINA_May_Fig3anim-2.gif</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/?p=13313</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>All-Female Salamanders Have Superior Powers of Regeneration</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/GaUQ0SqL33k/</link><description>

The Amazons were a mythical race of warrior women who, in one version of the story, removed their right breasts to be more hardcore. But an all-female race of salamanders doesn't suffer from missing body parts. In fact, these animals have super-powered regeneration: when they lose an appendage, they can grow it back much more quickly than other salamanders do.

The secret lies somewhere in the salamanders' bizarre genetics. "They sort of defy definition," says Rob Denton, a graduate studen</description><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 15:14:44 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/inkfish/?p=2960</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/inkfish/files/2016/05/IMG_1439_smaller-1024x368.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/inkfish/files/2016/05/IMG_1439_smaller-1024x368.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/inkfish/?p=2960</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Talking Death on Earth with Zoologist Jules Howard</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/3ycHwPm1MKw/</link><description>

I process words for a living. A lot of those words, in peer-reviewed journals or rough first drafts, are not the liveliest of reads. I'm not complaining. It is, after all, how I justify a high-carb diet. A girl's gotta fuel her gray matter.

So when a book lands on my desk that's funny and clever but also chock full of science, a book that's a genuine pleasure to read, I get excited. Such was British zoologist Jules Howard's 2014 title, Sex on Earth: A Celebration of Animal Reproduction (e</description><pubDate>Mon, 09 May 2016 15:00:21 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/deadthings/?p=42</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/deadthings/files/2016/05/DeathOnEarth-191x300.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/deadthings/files/2016/05/DeathOnEarth-191x300.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/deadthings/?p=42</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Satellite images show Fort McMurray Canada under assault from the rampaging wildfire nicknamed "the beast"</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/A_Cvb_aQunI/</link><description>

Fueled by dry conditions and temperatures in the 80s, the rampaging Canadian wildfire nicknamed "the beast" is expected to grow to more than 700 square miles today — an area equivalent in size to New York City.

The blaze has forced the evacuation of Fort McMurray, Alberta's oil boom-town city of more than 80,000 people located 400 miles north of Calgary. An estimated 1,600 homes and other buildings have burned so far. Luckily, winds today are blowing the flames to the northeast, away from</description><pubDate>Sat, 07 May 2016 21:16:56 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/?p=13264</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/files/2016/05/McMurray-false.gif</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/files/2016/05/McMurray-false.gif</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/imageo/?p=13264</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Ketamine and Depression: A Breakthrough?</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/2r64WtVVFqw/</link><description>In recent years there has been great research interest in ketamine as an antidepressant. Ketamine, a drug better-known for its use as an anaesthetic (and a recreational drug in lower doses) is claimed to have powerful, rapid-acting antidepressant effects, even in depressed patients who have not responded to more conventional drugs. However, its mechanism of action remains unclear.


Now, in a major new Nature paper, Baltimore researchers Panos Zanos and colleagues say that ketamine itself is </description><pubDate>Sat, 07 May 2016 09:17:18 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/?p=7728</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/files/2016/05/ketamine_hnk-1.png</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/files/2016/05/ketamine_hnk-1.png</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/neuroskeptic/?p=7728</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>MESSENGER's Final Word on Mercury</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/-CDxyxrsgG8/</link><description>

When Mercury glides across the face of the sun Monday, you’re not going to see much more than a speck — if you have the right equipment.

But thanks to NASA’s MESSENGER, we can see the planet’s peaks, valleys and pockmarks in unprecedented detail. On Friday, the Planetary Data System released the first global elevation model of Mercury’s surface, giving scientists an opportunity dive deeper into the planet’s geologic history.


Gone But Never Forgotten
MESSENGER’s operations ended just</description><pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 18:43:05 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15177</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/Mercury_DEM_white_robinson_grid_nomen-1.png</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/files/2016/05/Mercury_DEM_white_robinson_grid_nomen-1.png</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/d-brief/?p=15177</feedburner:origLink></item><item><title>Fossil of the Day: The Marine Reptile that Really Sucked</title><link>http://feedproxy.google.com/~r/DiscoverTopStories/~3/p3prm72ZNG0/</link><description>

Hear the word "hammerhead" and you probably think of sharks in the family Sphyrnidae, or perhaps the locals that were less than welcoming to Riddick and other delicious humans in Pitch Black.

You probably do not think of a Triassic marine reptile that bears an uncanny resemblance to an old Hoover upright.





Atopodenatus unicus, about 9 feet long, lived a quiet life some 242 million years ago, minding its own herbivorous business, just swimming along the ocean floor sucking up veg</description><pubDate>Fri, 06 May 2016 18:00:18 GMT</pubDate><guid isPermaLink="false">http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/deadthings/?p=60</guid><media:content>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/deadthings/files/2016/05/114449_web.jpg</media:content><media:thumbnail>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/deadthings/files/2016/05/114449_web.jpg</media:thumbnail><feedburner:origLink>http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/deadthings/?p=60</feedburner:origLink></item></channel></rss>
